elements.text:
1. Introduction to respiratory system
2. Physical aspects and mechanics of ventilation
3. Factors affecting ventilation
4. O2 & CO2 transport
5. Acid-base balance 
6. Regulation of breathing
Part 1 – Introduction to the respiratory system

What is the purpose of this entire process?
Ventilation (breathing)

items.text: To move air into and out of respiratory system.
External respiration – gas exchange between air and capillaries in the lungs
Internal respiration – gas exchange between systemic capillaries and tissues of the body
Pressure gradients generate diffusion
Cellular respiration
Conducting zone and respiratory zone
Outside the lungs – nasal passages  pharynx  epiglottis  larynx (glottis)
Inside the lungs – trachea (1)  bronchus (2 branches)  bronchiole  …  terminal bronchiole
Respiratory bronchiole  …  alveolar sacs

elements.text:
What happens to individual airway diameter and length as go deeper into the lungs?
Collective x-sectional area?

items.text: Passage of air
Warming
Humidification
Filtration
Immune surveillance

elements.text: What is the source of the water vapor?
Role of the mucociliary apparatus in removal of particulates.

items.text: Passage of air
Gas exchange
Immune surveillance

elements.text: Alveoli Are the Site of Gas Exchange

items.text: Total # = ~300 x 106
0.25 - 0.5 mm in diameter
Total area = 60 - 80 m2
Type I alveolar cells – the major lining cells, accounts for 95-97% of total surface area
Type II alveolar cells – production of surfactants
Air-blood barrier = ~0.3 m

elements.text: Scanning electron micrograph of capillary net over alveoli.
Very Thin Diffusion Barrier for Gas Exchange

Layers of respiratory membrane:
1. Fluid layer with surfactant.
2. Type I alveolar cell membranes.
(3. Narrow interstitial space.)
4. Capillary endothelial cell membranes.

Thoracic cavity surrounded by rib cage (chest wall) and the respiratory muscles. 
Pleural (intra-pleural) space

items.text: Thin fluid layer between visceral pleura covering lungs (visceral) and parietal pleura lining thoracic cavity walls.
*Air-free, potential space -> lungs cling to inside of thorax.

elements.text: Diaphragm – muscle between thoracic & abdominal cavities.

items.text: 1. Contraction of diaphragm   thoracic vol vertically
2. Parasternal and external intercostals contract  raising the ribs   thoracic vol laterally (horizontally)

elements.text:
Quiet expiration – passive process, relaxation of inspiratory muscles.
Forced expiration – active process assisted by the abdominal muscles.
Part 2 – Physical aspects and mechanics of ventilation

items.text: At a constant temperature   P1V1 = P2V2
Thoracic expansion and contraction -> air movement
How do we get O2 into the body and CO2 out of the body?
Ventilation = air in and out of lungs
Results from pressure differences (gradient) induced by changes in lung volumes
Pressure (P) gradient – results in net gas flow & diffusion from high P to low P
Similar principles apply to respiration
For PO2 – alveolar space > blood plasma > interstitial fluid > cytosol > mitochondria
For PCO2 – mitochondria > cytosol > interstitial fluid > blood plasma > alveoli
Anatomically correct version of the last slide.

elements.text:
Atmospheric – always 760 mm Hg
Alveolar (Intrapulmonary) – at rest, during inspiration, during expiration
Pleural (Intrapleural) – at rest, during inspiration, during expiration
Natural Properties of Lungs & Chest Wall

The lung can be viewed as a passive, elastic container.
The “pleural space” contains only a film of fluid, so lungs normally remain in contact with the chest walls.
The lung tends to recoil inward and the chest wall outward
*These recoil forces in opposite directions create a negative (sub-atmospheric) pleural pressure: -3 to -4 mm Hg relative to atmospheric and alveolar pressures.
-> Lungs expand and contract along with the thoracic cavity.
What happens if the pleural space is disrupted by air or fluid?

Mediastinum separates each side of thorax.
Air (pneumothorax) or fluid (hydrothorax, generically) -> relative negative pressure lost -> lung lobes collapse.
New pressure gradient -> pneumothorax.
Left-sided pneumothorax with a chest tube in place.
CT scan of right-sided hydropneumothorax. A = air, B = fluid.

Ventilation occurs as a result of pressure gradients induced by changes in lung volume. 
During inspiration:

items.text: Contraction of inspiratory muscles    chest vol   pleural vol   pleural P    lung vol   alveolar P
 atmospheric P > alveolar P  generation of pressure gradient  air to flows into the lung
Energy -> muscular contraction -> works against the elastic recoil forces of the lung.
 lung vol   alveolar pressure above atmosphere (alveolar P > atmospheric P)  air goes out
Elastic recoil forces of the lung contribute to change in pressure gradient.

elements.text:
Relative pressures
Pleural P – ALWAYS lower than alveolar P & atmospheric P

items.text: ALWAYS negative (sub-atmospheric)

elements.text:
Alveolar P – may be “-” (inspiration) or “+” (expiration)
Trans-pulmonary P = D P across the wall of the lung

items.text: = Alveolar P – Pleural P
Always positive
Increasing difference vs. decreasing difference.

elements.text:
Lung volumes - tidal vol (TV), inspiratory reserve vol (IRV), expiratory reserve vol (ERV), and residual vol (RV).
Lung capacities – inspiratory capacity (IC), functional residual capacity (FRC), vital capacity (VC), and total lung capacity (TLC).

items.text: Capacity – sum of more than 1 volume
Timed vital capacity (or forced expiration volume for the 1st second, FEV1) – normal is > 80%

elements.text:
Dead space = regions of the airways that are ventilated but no gas exchange occurs.
Physiologic dead space = anatomic dead space + alveolar dead space
Anatomic dead space

items.text: *Air in the conducting airways of respiratory system that does NOT participate in the gas exchange.
Not all of the inspired air reaches the alveoli.
Inhaled fresh air mixed with expired air in anatomical dead space.
*Air in the respiratory zone that is ventilated but does NOT participate in gas exchange.
Due to lack of blood flow to those alveoli.

elements.text:
VA = alveolar ventilation
Q = blood flow
For efficient gas exchange (O2 in, CO2 out), want level of ventilation to match blood flow in alveoli. V/Q ≈ 0.8
VA is greater in the apices of the lungs -> high V/Q – overventilated and underperfused
Q is greater in the basal lung lobes -> low V/Q – underventilated and overperfused

Pulmonary arterioles try to maximize V/Q ratio ≈ 0.8
Systemic arterioles (e.g., muscle beds) dilate if arterial O2 levels (PaO2) are low -> more blood with O2 delivered.
Pulmonary arterioles constrict if alveolar O2 levels (PAO2) are low. Dilate if PAO2 high. 
What does this accomplish if PAO2 is low in individual alveoli or a region of lung? 
If PAO2 is high in alveoli or a region of lung?
V/Q mismatch occurs with different disease states.

items.text: Change in lung vol per change in transpulmonary P
Compliance = V/P
100 x more distensible than a balloon
Compliance is affected by elastance (2) ; and surface tension (3)

elements.text: 2. Elastance (elasticity) – recoil ability, resistance to distension

items.text: Elasticity = 1/compliance
Tendency to return to initial size after distension.
High content of elastin proteins
Elastic tension  during inspiration and  during expiration

elements.text:
Balloon analogy
Diseases can alter compliance and elasticity (ahead).

items.text: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v7477AMrUyc

elements.text: 3. Surface tension – to be discussed in the next slides

Thin film of liquid (water) lines alveoli.
Surface tension (T)

items.text: Reflects the work needed to  surface area of a liquid at an interface.

elements.text: Law of Laplace – P in alveoli is directly proportional to surface tension; and inversely proportional to radius of alveoli.

items.text: T is the same for same interface.
For the same T, smaller alveoli have higher P to collapse than larger alveoli.
r=2 (P=T) vs. r=1 (P=2T)  collapse of smaller alveoli
 P   compliance  takes more energy to expand.

elements.text: What helps keep surface tension from collapsing our alveoli?

items.text: Produced by type II alveolar cells (pneumocytes).
1. Phospholipids – amphipathic
2. Surfactant proteins – help distribute phospholipids.
Lower surface tension   compliance.
Prevent collapse of smaller alveoli.
As alveoli radius decreases, surfactant’s ability to lower surface tension increases.
Occurs in ~10% of premature neonates.
Underdeveloped anatomy.
Surfactant insufficiency.
Every breath is like the first breath.

elements.text:
Ex., pulmonary fibrosis
Accumulation of fibrous connective tissue in alveolar wall.
 vital capacity; normal FEV1;  compliance
*Reduced lung volume
Evident in which phase of ventilation?

Ex., asthma, cystic fibrosis
Vital capacity may be normal; FEV1 is < 80%
*Reduced airflow
Evident in which phase of ventilation?
Emphysema – alveolar tissue is destroyed,  compliance

items.text: Chronic progressive; reduces surface area for gas exchange
Cigarette smoking   WBC proteinases secretion   destruction tissue proteins  collapse of alveolar sacs
Asthma & emphysema

elements.text: *Dalton’s Law – the law of partial pressures

items.text: The pressure exerted by each component in a gaseous mixture is independent of other gases in the mixture, and the total pressure of the mixture of gases is equal to the sum of the separate pressures.
PB = PCO2 + PO2 + PN2 + PH2O = 760 mm Hg atmospheric pressure
Movement of individual gases

elements.text:
Henry’s Law: C = kP
Concentration of gas in liquid = solubility x partial pressure in liquid.
At equilibrium, partial pressure is equal on both gas and liquid sides, but # of molecules varies depending on solubility of the gas.
Partial pressure of each gas is the same for both.

Gases can exist in either in gas phase or in liquid phase (dissolved in blood plasma).
Dissolved gas molecules also exert partial P.
 Gas molecules dissolve in blood plasma   [gas] in blood plasma   P.
At equilibrium, the # of gas molecules entering (dissolving in) the plasma equals the # of gas molecules leaving the plasma to air phase.
At equilibrium does not mean that the # of gas molecules (concentration) in the air and the liquid are equal.

items.text: How do we get O2 into the body and CO2 out of the body?  (Ventilation)
A) In and out of the lungs:
Gas exchange results from pressure differences (gradient) induced by changes in lung volumes.
B) From the lungs to the cells in the body (O2) and from the cells in the body to the lungs (CO2):
*For PO2 – alveolar space PAO2 > blood plasma PaO2 > interstitial fluid > cytosol > mitochondria
*For PCO2 – mitochondria > cytosol > interstitial fluid > blood plasma PvCO2 > alveoli PACO2

elements.text:
PA = partial pressure alveolar
Pa = partial pressure arterial
Pv = partial pressure venous

Rate of blood flow through the pulmonary circulation = flow rate through the systemic circulation.
Pulmonary vascular resistance is lower -> lower BP.

items.text: Structure of pulmonary arteries – contains less smooth muscle
What purposes might this serve?

elements.text: Look at all those systemic vessels vs. much less pulmonary vessels!
Please know the path of blood through the heart, lungs, and systemic circulation.

Generation of pressure gradients for net gas exchange.
What is the P gradient for O2 in the lungs (PvO2 vs. PaO2)? 
For CO2?
Assuming correctly that every O2 molecule consumed -> one CO2 molecule (roughly)…why the big difference between O2 and CO2?
CO2 Diffuses Much More Readily in Plasma Than O2

items.text: Solubility coefficient CO2/solubility coefficient O2 = 0.57/0.024 = 23.75/1.
CO2 has a much higher diffusion rate in fluid/tissue phase vs. O2.
Need a much higher diffusion gradient for O2 to supply enough molecules to tissues to produce ATP.
Much lower diffusion gradient for CO2 needed to bring enough molecules to lung for exhalation.

elements.text: O2 is transported in blood in:

items.text: 1. Dissolved O2 (< 2%)
Each Hb has 4 polypeptide chains and 4 hemes
*1 heme binds to 1 O2, thus 1 Hb binds to 4 O2 maximally

elements.text:
Oxyhemoglobin (Hb-O2) – O2 binds to Fe2+  of heme
Deoxyhemoglobin – Hb only, no O2, also contain Fe2+ (oxygenation, not oxidation)
Oxygen-carrying capacity of blood determined by its [Hb].

items.text: Anemia - ↓ RBCs -> [Hb] below normal.
Polycythemia - ↑ RBCs -> [Hb] above normal.
Hb production controlled by erythropoietin.
Production stimulated by PCO2 delivery to kidneys.

elements.text: Methemoglobin – Fe2+ oxidized -> Fe3+, cannot bind with O2.

items.text: Brown blood, brownish-blue mucous membranes.
The bond with CO is 210x stronger than the bond with O2.
Transport of O2 to tissues is impaired.

elements.text:
X-axis denotes PO2 (mm Hg)
Y-axis denotes O2 saturation rate (%) or O2 content (mL O2 /dL blood)
The higher the PO2, the higher Hb-O2 saturation

items.text: Gas exchange at alveolar space → loading of O2 → oxygenated blood → PO2 = 100 mm Hg → O2-Hb is ~98%.
At peripheral tissues → unloading of O2 → deoxygenated blood → PO2 = to 40 mm Hg → O2-Hb is ~ 75%.
The physiological range of represents the flatter portion of the sigmoid Hb-O2 curve
Only ~20-25% of O2 from Hb-O2 is unloaded
How about the steep portion of the curve?
What happens to unloading of O2 when PO2 ↓ ↓?

elements.text: Hb-O2 Saturation: Affinity of Hb for O2 Changes

Structure of Hb changes conformation as subsequent O2’s bind or depart.
 Affinity of Hb for O2 increases as more O2 binds -> Hb holds O2 more tightly at higher PO2’s (pulmonary capillary beds).
Affinity of Hb for O2 decreases as more O2 departs -> Hb holds O2 less tightly at lower PO2’s (tissue capillary beds).
Hb-O2 Saturation: A More Helpful Figure
This figure incorporates the role of affinity of Hb for O2 based on PO2.

Shifts in the curve reflect the effect of a physiological factor on affinity of Hb for O2.
A shift of curve to left increases affinity of Hb for O2. What does this mean in the lungs? In the tissues?
A shift of curve to the right decreases affinity of Hb for O2. What does this mean in the lungs? In the tissues?

For each factor, ask yourself whether the change will result in a greater need for O2 in the tissues. “Yes” -> right shift. 
Factors affecting O2-Hb affinity

items.text: ↓ pH (acidosis) → right shift
↑ PCO2 (suggests hypoxemia) → right shift (Bohr effect)
↑ temperature → right shift
↑ [2,3-DPG] in RBC → right shift

elements.text: 2,3-DPG Alters Affinity of Hb for O2

2,3-diphosphoglycerate or 2,3 bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG)
Metabolic by-product of glycolysis in RBCs.
O2 inhibits its production.
2,3-DPG binds Hb -> decrease in affinity for O2 -> right shift where more O2 is released in tissues.
2,3-DPG production ↑ with hypoxemic conditions

items.text: Anemia
High altitudes
Some forms of chronic lung disease

elements.text:
Red pigment found exclusively in striated muscle (skeletal and cardiac muscle fibers).
*Has a higher affinity for O2 than Hb.
Ferrying effect – acts as a “go-between” in the transfer of O2 from blood to the mitochondria within muscle cells.
O2 storage function – in cardiac muscles.

items.text: Acidosis – pH < 7.35  ↑ H+ ions
Alkalosis – pH > 7.45  ↓ H+ ions

elements.text: 2 major classes of acids in body:

items.text: A volatile acid can be converted to a gas
CO2 in bicarbonate buffer system can be breathed out (lungs).
All other acids are non-volatile and cannot leave blood
Non-volatile acids – lactic acid, fatty acids, ketone bodies.
Need to bind to buffer molecules.

elements.text:
Buffers in the body include HCO3–, PO42–, proteins including Hb.
Kidneys – excrete H+ into urine, reabsorb HCO3- from urine (Part II).

CO2 + H2O ⇌ H2CO3 ⇌ H+ + HCO3-
Carbon dioxide ⇌ carbonic acid ⇌ bicarbonate
CA = carbonic anhydrase enzyme

items.text: Catalyzes reaction both directions.
Higher expression in RBCs, gastric mucosa, pancreatic exocrine cells, renal tubules.
Why would it be in all these tissues?
pH = 6.1 + log ( [HCO3-] / [CO2] )
[CO2] is adjusted by lungs, [HCO3-] by kidneys

elements.text: Free H+ in nmol/L concentrations, free HCO3- in mmol/L concentrations.

items.text: What effect does adding HCO3- have on plasma [H+]?
What does increased [HCO3-] do to pH? Decreased?
What effect does adding CO2 have on plasma [H+]?
What does increased [CO2] do to pH? Decreased?

elements.text:
*Ventilation usually adjusted to metabolic rate to maintain normal CO2 levels.
What does increased respiratory rate or ventilation do to plasma [CO2]?
What does decreased respiratory rate or ventilation do to plasma [CO2]?
So how would the lungs (controlled by the brain) respond to ↑ plasma [CO2], ↑ plasma [H+], and ↓ plasma pH?
And how would the lungs (controlled by the brain) respond to ↓ plasma [CO2], ↓ plasma [H+], and ↑ plasma pH?

items.text: Caused by hypoventilation – CNS depression, neuromuscular disorders, chest wall restriction, pulmonary tissue disease, airway obstruction.
Accumulation of CO2 in the tissues   PCO2 in blood   pH in blood
Caused by hyperventilation – CNS disease, acute asthma, hypoxemia.
Excessive loss of CO2   PCO2   pH in blood
Where is the H+ when CO2 is exhaled?

elements.text: Now You Are Ready for CO2 Transport
CO2 transported in the blood in 3 forms:

items.text: Dissolved CO2 (10%) – accounts for PCO2
Carbaminohemoglobin (20%)
Unloading of O2  Hb-CO2 formed
CO2 does NOT bind heme in Hb.

elements.text:
3 things to remember to understand this:
Carbonic anhydrase is located in RBCs.
CO2 readily crosses plasma membranes.
Bicarb (HCO3-) needs to be transported across plasma membranes. Antiporter exchanges chloride (Cl-) for bicarb.
Now You Are Ready for CO2 Transport

items.text: Chloride shift into RBCs
Reverse chloride shift out of RBCs

elements.text:
For metabolic homeostasis, the frequency and amplitude of breathing must respond to metabolic changes. 
Sensors: Chemoreceptors for chemical changes, mechanoreceptors for mechanical changes.
Integrator: Brain

items.text: Continuous display of voluntary and involuntary actions.
Voluntary action is done by cerebrum, hypothalamus, limbic system (anger).
Involuntary action is done by the brain stem respiratory centers (medulla oblongata and pons).
Brain stem respiratory centers
Rhythmicity center (medulla)
Apneustic center (pons)
Pneumotaxic center (pons)

elements.text:
2 groups of chemoreceptors that monitor changes in blood PCO2, PO2, and pH.
Central chemoreceptors:

items.text: Located in medulla, different from the rhythmicity center.
More sensitive to blood PCO2 than blood pH (due to the BBB).
Carotid and aortic bodies
Directly detect changes in PO2
Indirectly detect changes in PCO2 through pH
H2O + CO2  H2CO3  H+ + HCO3-
More sensitive to changes in blood pH than PO2

elements.text:
Baroreceptors: Carotid sinuses and aortic arch
Chemoreceptors: Carotid bodies and aortic bodies

Detect mechanical changes of breathing (volume and frequency).
Influence the brain stem respiratory control centers via sensory fibers in vagus nerves.
Pulmonary stretch receptors (PSR) – detect volume changes; present in the smooth muscle of the airways; slowly adapting; activated during inspiration to force expiration.
Hering-Breuer inflation reflex:

items.text: Triggered to prevent over-inflation of the lungs.
A.k.a. – rapidly adaptive receptors on Aδ fibers
Detect frequency of breathing
Respond to smoke, smog, and particulates -> cause coughing
Sensory neurons located in lungs
Stimulated by noxious substances such as capsaicin
Produces initial apnea -> rapid, shallow breathing
generate automatic basic rhythm of breathing
Basic rhythm is irregular, erratic, and unstable. It is NOT the normal rhythm
Consists of interacting neurons that fire either during inspiration (I neurons) or expiration (E neurons)
Quiet expiration is a passive process that occurs when the I neurons are inhibited

elements.text:
Dorsal respiratory group (DRG) – inspiration
Ventral respiratory group (VRG) - expiration

Basic rhythm generated by the medullary rhythmicity center must be adjusted by pons.
Apneustic center:

items.text: Promotes long inspiration and sharp expiration (apneustic breathing).
Needs to work together with apneustic center.
Antagonizes the apneustic center’s effects.
Inhibits inspiration, thus the normal rhythm.
